(Same as JS 324 1)  This course will be taught online. It meets for two synchronous 75-minute sessions per week on MW.
Topic Title: The Holocaust in the Courtroom: A Legal and Historical Analysis
This course satisfies the new Religion major requirement:- Tradition-Judaism, Theme. 
This course will focus on the way in which the Holocaust has fared in the courtroom particularly in terms of laws against genocide and crimes against humanity.  We will approach the issue from both a legal and a historical perspective.  Is the courtroom the right place to adjudicate matters of genocide? 
 Can it serve justice when the topic is Holocaust denial: Special attention will be given to the Nuremberg Tribunals (1945-7),  the Eichmann Trial (1961), Auschwitz Frankfurt Trial (1963),  Zundel Trial (1985, 1988), Irving v. Lipstadt (2000) and the Demjanjuk Trials (1988, 1998, 2009).   Students will be expected to write papers on some aspect of the treatment of genocide in the courtroom, whether the topic has been covered in class or not.
course_description: An analysis of the sociopolitical background and the horror of the Holocaust, followed by the popular as well as the theological responses of the Jewish and Christian communities.
